It can be used for all kinds of valuable data.     <script data-react-helmet="true">
     window.dataLayer = window.dataLayer || [];

              var data = {"documentTitle":"Explainer: What is a blockchain? | MIT Technology Review","articleId":"143477","articleTopic":"Blockchain","articleSubtopic":"Bitcoin","author":"MIT Technology Review Editors","contentType":"post","paywallType":"metered","publishDate":"2018-04-23","storyFormat":"Full Story","updatedDate":"2020-04-02","wordCount":"860","siteEngine":"wp.irving"};

              window.dataLayer.push(data);

What is a blockchain?","description":"We take a look at who invented blockchains, what applications they’re useful for, and how they are made.","url":"https://www.technologyreview.com/2018/04/23/143477/explainer-what-is-a-blockchain/","dateCreated":"2018-04-23T04:00:00-04:00","datePublished":"2018-04-23T04:00:00-04:00","dateModified":"2020-04-02T16:12:01-04:00","articleSection":"Blockchain","wordCount":860,"mainEntityOfPage":{"@type":"WebPage","@id":"https://www.technologyreview.com/2018/04/23/143477/explainer-what-is-a-blockchain/"},"publisher":{"@type":"Organization","name":"MIT Editors"}}},"children":[],"componentGroups":{"default":[]}},{"name":"schema","config":{"type":"BreadcrumbList","data":{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"BreadcrumbList","itemListElement":[{"@type":"ListItem","position":1,"name":"Blockchain","item":{"@type":"Thing","@id":"https://www.technologyreview.com/topic/blockchain/"}},{"@type":"ListItem","position":2,"name":"Bitcoin","item":{"@type":"Thing","@id":"https://www.technologyreview.com/topic/blockchain/bitcoin/"}},{"@type":"ListItem","position":3,"name":"Explainer: What is a blockchain?","item":{"@type":"Thing","@id":"https://www.technologyreview.com/2018/04/23/143477/explainer-what-is-a-blockchain/"}}]}},"children":[],"componentGroups":{"default":[]}},{"name":"content-area","config":{"themeName":"contentWrap"},"children":[{"name":"column-area","config":{"themeName":"fullStory"},"children":[{"name":"content-area","config":{},"children":[{"name":"content-header","config":{"authors":[],"hideFeaturedImage":false,"publishDate":"April 23, 2018","title":"Explainer: What is a blockchain?","deck":"We take a look at who invented blockchains, what applications they’re useful for, and how they are made.","eyebrow":{"link":"https://www.technologyreview.com/topic/blockchain/","color":"#007fab","content":"Blockchain","customEyebrow":"","subTopic":"Bitcoin","subTopicLink":"https://www.technologyreview.com/topic/blockchain/bitcoin/"},"themeName":"simple"},"children":[{"name":"byline","config":{"authors":[{"name":"MIT Technology Review Editors","link":"https://www.technologyreview.com/author/mit-technology-review-editors/"}]},"children":[],"componentGroups":{"default":[]}}],"componentGroups":{"default":[]}},{"name":"content-body","config":{"teaseCTA":"Read more","truncatedCTA":"Read the whole story","summaryBullets":false,"postFormat":"full-story","isSponsored":false,"sponsored":[],"wordCount":853,"showMagazine":true,"magazine":143379,"themeName":"simple"},"children":[{"name":"gutenberg-content","config":{"postFormat":"full-story"},"children":[{"name":"html","config":{"content":"\u003ch3>What is it?\u003c/h3>\u003cp>A \u003cspan class=\"l-article-annotation\" data-icon=\"\" data-annotation=\"Though some blockchains require permission to access, “open” blockchains like those underlying Bitcoin and Ethereum are accessible to anyone, meaning the database is public information.\">public\u003ca href=\"#public\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">\u003csup data-annotation-super=\"true\">1\u003c/sup>\u003c/a>\u003c/span>, \u003cspan class=\"l-article-annotation\" data-icon=\"\" data-annotation=\"It’s next to impossible for bad actors to tamper with data encoded in a blockchain, if it’s properly set up.\">permanent\u003ca href=\"#permanent\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">\u003csup data-annotation-super=\"true\">2\u003c/sup>\u003c/a>\u003c/span>, \u003cspan class=\"l-article-annotation\" data-icon=\"\" data-annotation=\"Old transactions can’t be changed in a properly functioning blockchain; only new ones can be added.\">append-only\u003ca href=\"#append-only\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">\u003csup data-annotation-super=\"true\">3\u003c/sup>\u003c/a> \u003c/span>\u003cspan class=\"l-article-annotation\" data-icon=\"\" data-annotation=\"No single entity owns or controls a public blockchain. A network of computers maintains and secures the database, and each participant, or “node,” stores a copy. \">distributed\u003ca href=\"#distributed\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">\u003csup data-annotation-super=\"true\">4\u003c/sup>\u003c/a> \u003c/span>\u003cspan class=\"l-article-annotation\" data-icon=\"\" data-annotation=\"The original blockchain, Bitcoin, is a ledger for tracking currency balances. But the same basic method can work for all kinds of digital assets.\">ledger\u003ca href=\"#Adding\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">\u003csup data-annotation-super=\"true\">5\u003c/sup>\u003c/a>\u003c/span>.\u003c/p>"},"children":[],"componentGroups":{"default":[]}},{"name":"mittr-plugin-extension/magazine-story","config":{"postID":"143379","title":"The blockchain issue","permalink":"https://www.technologyreview.com/magazines/the-blockchain-issue/","issueDate":"May 2018","subscribeLink":"https://www.technologyreview.com/subscribe","coverImage":{"src":"https://wp.technologyreview.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/mj18cover-01-3.jpg?w=490","width":490,"height":628}},"children":[],"componentGroups":{"default":[]}},{"name":"html","config":{"content":"\u003ch3>What’s that?\u003c/h3>\u003cp>A mathematical structure for storing data in a way that is nearly impossible to fake. It can be used for \u003ca href=\"https://www.technologyreview.com/s/610331/when-the-cryptocurrency-bubble-pops-these-tokens-are-built-to-survive/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">all kinds of valuable data\u003c/a>.\u003c/p>\u003ch3>Who created the first blockchain?\u003c/h3>\u003cp>“I’ve been working on a new electronic cash system that’s fully peer-to-peer, with no trusted third party.” These are the words of Satoshi Nakamoto, the mysterious creator of Bitcoin, in a message sent to a cryptography-focused mailing list in October 2008. Included was a link to \u003ca href=\"https://bitcoin.org/en/bitcoin-paper\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">a nine-page white paper\u003c/a> describing a technology that some are now convinced will disrupt the financial system.\u003c/p>"},"children":[],"componentGroups":{"default":[]}},{"name":"mittr-plugin-extension/content-list","config":{},"children":[{"name":"gutenberg-content","config":{},"children":[{"name":"mittr-plugin-extension/content-list-item","config":{"title":"Enforcement","description":"\u003cp>Early civilizations used threat of force as retribution for dealing in bad faith when engaging in trade.\u003c/p>"},"children":[],"componentGroups":{"default":[]}},{"name":"mittr-plugin-extension/content-list-item","config":{"title":"Institutions","description":"\u003cp>The emergence of governments and banks provided organized, central authorities to which we could outsource trust—as long as we trusted them.\u003c/p>"},"children":[],"componentGroups":{"default":[]}},{"name":"mittr-plugin-extension/content-list-item","config":{"title":"The Network","description":"\u003cp>Blockchains distributed across thousands of computers can mechanize trust, opening the door to new ways of organizing “decentralized” enterprises and institutions. \u003c/p>"},"children":[],"componentGroups":{"default":[]}}],"componentGroups":{"default":[]}}],"componentGroups":{"default":[]}},{"name":"html","config":{"content":"\u003cp>Nakamoto mined the first bitcoins in January 2009, and with that, the cryptocurrency era was born. But while its origin is shadowy, the technology that made it possible, which we now call blockchain, did not arise out the blue. Nakamoto combined established cryptography tools with methods derived from decades of computer science research to enable a public network of participants who don’t necessarily trust each other to agree, over and over, that a shared accounting ledger reflects the truth. This makes it virtually impossible for someone to spend the same bitcoin twice, solving a problem that had hindered previous attempts to create digital cash. And, crucially, it eliminates the need for a central authority to mediate electronic exchange of the currency.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Bitcoin’s popularity began to grow quickly in 2011, after \u003ca href=\"https://gawker.com/the-underground-website-where-you-can-buy-any-drug-imag-30818160\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">a Gawker article\u003c/a> exposed Silk Road, a Bitcoin-powered online drug marketplace. Imitators called “altcoins” began to emerge, often using Bitcoin’s open-source code. Within two years, the total value of bitcoins in circulation had passed $1 billion.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Soon, technologists realized that blockchains could be used to track other things besides money. In 2013, 19-year-old Vitalik Buterin proposed \u003ca href=\"https://www.technologyreview.com/s/612507/ethereum-thinks-it-can-change-the-world-its-running-out-of-time-to-prove-it/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Ethereum\u003c/a>, which would record not only currency transactions but also the status of computer programs called smart contracts. Launched in 2015, Ethereum—and now a host of competitors and imitators—promises to make possible a new generation of applications that look and feel like today’s web apps but are powered by decentralized cryptocurrency networks instead of a company’s servers.&nbsp;\u003c/p>\u003ch3>\u003ca id=\"public\">\u003c/a>1. A transaction is born\u003c/h3>\u003cp>In Bitcoin, a transaction is the transfer of cryptocurrency from one person (Alice) to another (Bob). In Ethereum, which includes a built-in programming language that can be used to automate transactions, there are multiple kinds. Alice can send cryptocurrency to Bob. Or someone can create a transaction that places a line of code, called a \u003ca href=\"https://www.technologyreview.com/s/612443/blockchain-smart-contracts-can-finally-have-a-real-world-impact/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">smart contract\u003c/a>, on the blockchain. Alice and Bob can then send money to an account this program controls, to trigger it to run if certain conditions encoded in the contract are met. A smart contract can also send transactions to the blockchain in which it is embedded.\u003c/p> \u003cfigure class=\"wp-block-image alignfull size-large\">\u003cimg src=\"https://cdn.technologyreview.com/i/images/explainer-images-1.png?sw=700&cx=229&cy=41&cw=655&ch=501\" alt=\"a diagram of two simple transactions on a blockchain\">\u003c/figure> \u003ch3>\u003ca id=\"permanent\">\u003c/a>2. The transaction is broadcast to a peer-to-peer network\u003c/h3>\u003cp>Let’s say Alice wants to send some money to Bob. To do so, Alice creates a transaction on her computer that must reference a past transaction on the blockchain in which she received sufficient funds, as well as her private key to the funds and Bob’s address. That transaction is then sent out to other computers, or “nodes,” in the network. The nodes will validate the transaction as long as it has followed the appropriate rules. Then mining nodes (more on those in step 3) will accept it, and it will become part of a new block.&nbsp;\u003c/p> \u003cfigure class=\"wp-block-image alignfull size-large\">\u003cimg src=\"https://cdn.technologyreview.com/i/images/explainer-images-2.png?sw=700&cx=147&cy=0&cw=809&ch=552\" alt=\"a diagram of a \" of transactions on a>\u003c/figure> \u003ch3>\u003ca id=\"append-only\">\u003c/a>3. The race to create new blocks&nbsp;\u003c/h3>\u003cp>A subset of nodes, called miners, organize valid transactions into lists called blocks. A block in progress contains a list of recent valid transactions and a cryptographic reference to the previous block. In blockchain systems like Bitcoin and Ethereum, miners race to complete new blocks, a process that requires solving a labor-intensive mathematical puzzle, which is unique to each new block. The first miner to solve the puzzle will earn some cryptocurrency as a reward. The math puzzle involves randomly guessing at a number called a nonce. The nonce is combined with the other data in the block to create an encrypted digital fingerprint, called a hash.\u003c/p> \u003cfigure class=\"wp-block-image alignfull size-large\">\u003cimg src=\"https://cdn.technologyreview.com/i/images/explainer-images-3.png?sw=700&cx=209&cy=32&cw=703&ch=511\" alt=\"a diagram of a new block of transactions being verified\">\u003c/figure> \u003ch3>\u003ca id=\"distributed\">\u003c/a>4. Completing a new block\u003cstrong>&nbsp;\u003c/strong>\u003c/h3>\u003cp>The hash must meet certain conditions; if it doesn’t, the miner tries another random nonce and calculates the hash again. It takes an enormous number of tries to find a valid hash. This process deters hackers by making it hard to modify the ledger. While some blockchain entities use other systems to secure their chains, this approach, called proof of work, is the most thoroughly battle-tested.\u003cstrong>&nbsp;\u003c/strong>\u003c/p> \u003cfigure class=\"wp-block-image alignfull size-large\">\u003cimg src=\"https://cdn.technologyreview.com/i/images/explainer-images-4.png?sw=700&cx=185&cy=48&cw=736&ch=505\" alt=\"a diagram of a new block being sent to the network of blockchain miners for approval\">\u003c/figure> \u003ch3>\u003ca id=\"Adding\">\u003c/a>5. Adding a new block to the chain\u003c/h3>\u003cp>This is the final step in securing the ledger. When a mining node becomes the first to solve a new block’s crypto-puzzle, it sends the block to the rest of the network for approval, earning digital tokens in reward. Mining difficulty is encoded in the blockchain’s protocol; Bitcoin and Ethereum are designed to make it increasingly hard to solve a block over time. Since each block also contains a reference to the previous one, the blocks are mathematically chained together. Tampering with an earlier block would require repeating the proof of work for all the subsequent blocks in the chain.&nbsp;\u003c/p>\u003ch3>&nbsp;\u003c/h3> \u003cfigure class=\"wp-block-image alignfull size-large\">\u003cimg src=\"https://cdn.technologyreview.com/i/images/explainer-images-5.png?sw=700&cx=152&cy=60&cw=775&ch=436\" alt=\"a diagram of a new block of transactions being added to a blockchain\">\u003c/figure> experimental covid-19 vaccine has shown promising early results","authorLink":"https://www.technologyreview.com/author/charlotte-jee/","post_id":null},{"author":"James not one reason California’s covid-19 cases are soaring—there are many","authorLink":"https://www.technologyreview.com/author/james-temple/","post_id":null},{"author":"Charlotte policy","thumb_url_medium":"https://images.parsely.com/Z3IEZrwUBlQNIFGZpQlxOXn6WDk=/85x85/smart/https%3A//wp.technologyreview.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/School-risk-Covid-19.jpg%3Fresize%3D854%252C569","title":"Is it safe to send kids back to school?","authorLink":"https://www.technologyreview.com/author/charlotte-jee/","post_id":null},{"author":"Will Douglas plan to redesign the internet could make apps that no one            <rect height="6.51" width="7.25" x="430.66" y="2.39">
           </rect>
           <path d="M383,34.37h8.91c3.84,0,6,1.71,6,5.17s-2.08,5.23-6.13,5.23H383Zm15.95,31.41h8.53l-9.52-15.71c4.8-1.6,7.54-5.25,7.54-10.58a11.38,11.38,0,0,0-3.41-8.27c-2.24-2.29-5.12-3.57-10-3.57H375.42V65.78H383V51.06h7.1Z" transform="translate(-27.57 -27.65)">
           </path>
           <path d="M412.33,49.14c.64-3.57,2.51-5.87,6.35-5.87,3.31,0,5.6,2.4,5.81,5.87H412.33m-7.25,2.93c0,8.16,5.12,14.51,14.18,14.51,7,0,11.36-4.11,12.37-9h-7.15C423.69,59.7,422,61,419.21,61c-4.11,0-6.45-2.61-7-6.83h19.84c0-9.76-4.69-16.48-13.49-16.48-8,0-13.49,6.29-13.49,14.4" transform="translate(-27.57 -27.65)">
           </path>
           <polygon points="412.53 38.13 419.46 38.13 429.62 10.77 422.36 10.77 416.1 29.33 416 29.33 409.79 10.77 402.43 10.77 412.53 38.13">
           </polygon>
           <rect height="27.36" width="7.25" x="430.66" y="10.77">
           </rect>
           <path d="M474.34,49.14c.64-3.57,2.51-5.87,6.35-5.87,3.31,0,5.6,2.4,5.81,5.87H474.34m-7.25,2.93c0,8.16,5.12,14.51,14.19,14.51,7,0,11.36-4.11,12.37-9H486.5c-.8,2.08-2.45,3.36-5.28,3.36-4.11,0-6.45-2.61-7-6.83h19.84c0-9.76-4.69-16.48-13.49-16.48-8,0-13.49,6.29-13.49,14.4" transform="translate(-27.57 -27.65)">
           </path>
           <polygon points="472.7 38.13 479.25 38.13 484.27 20.2 484.38 20.2 489.23 38.13 495.84 38.13 504 10.77 496.96 10.77 492.27 28.24 492.16 28.24 487.31 10.77 481.12 10.77 476.54 28.24 476.43 28.24 471.9 10.77 464.7 10.77 472.7 38.13">
           </polygon>
           <rect height="38.13" width="7.24" x="43.09">
           </rect>
           <polygon points="52.15 0 52.15 6.51 62.36 6.51 62.36 38.13 69.67 38.13 69.67 6.51 79.88 6.51 79.88 0 52.15 0">
           </polygon>
           <polygon points="29.15 0 20.68 27.74 11.89 0 0 0 0 38.13 7.04 38.13 7.04 8 16.78 38.13 24.2 38.13 33.44 8 33.44 38.13 40.64 38.13 40.64 0 29.15 0">
           </polygon>
          </svg>
         </div>
        </a>
        <div class="headerTemplate__navigation--3N0Bf headerTemplate__isHeadroom--13Fwe">
         <div class="headerTemplate__menuRow--Yxgsz">
          <div class="headerTemplate__menu--1sSdR">
           <div class="menu__wrapper--2tnWs">
            <ul class="headerMenu__list--1bhxf">
             <li class="headerMenuItem__wrapper--3mUtz">
              <h3 class="headerMenuItem__parent--3Kg0H">
               Topics
              </h3>
             </li>
             <li class="headerMenuItem__wrapper--3mUtz">
              <h3 class="headerMenuItem__parent--3Kg0H">
               Magazine
              </h3>
             </li>
             <li class="headerMenuItem__wrapper--3mUtz">
              <h3 class="headerMenuItem__parent--3Kg0H">
               Newsletters
              </h3>
             </li>
             <li class="headerMenuItem__wrapper--3mUtz">
              <h3 class="headerMenuItem__parent--3Kg0H">
               Events
              </h3>
             </li>
            </ul>
           </div>
          </div>
          <button class="headerTemplate__button--3Ylhk" style="background:#fff" type="button">
           <span class="screen-reader-text">
            Expand menu
           </span>
           <span aria-hidden="true" class="headerTemplate__buttonVisualContent--3XM1h">
            <svg viewbox="0 0 31 19" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
             <g fill="#fff" fill-rule="evenodd" stroke="none" stroke-width="1">
              <g transform="translate(-768.000000, -2553.000000)">
               <g transform="translate(768.000000, 2554.000000)">
                <path d="M22,0 C25.3132,0 28,2.6868 28,6 C28,9.3132 25.3132,12 22,12 C18.6868,12 16,9.3132 16,6 C16,2.6868 18.6868,0 22,0 Z" stroke="#000" stroke-width="2">
                </path>
                <rect fill="#000" height="2" width="13" x="0" y="6">
                </rect>
                <rect fill="#000" height="2" width="13" x="0" y="10.5">
                </rect>
                <rect fill="#000" height="2" transform="translate(27.904988, 13.897039) rotate(53.000000) translate(-27.904988, -13.897039) " width="7" x="24.4049881" y="12.8970393">
                </rect>
                <rect fill="#000" height="2" width="20" x="0" y="15">
                </rect>
               </g>
              </g>
             </g>
            </svg>
           </span>
          </button>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </header>
     </div>
    </div>
    <main class="body__content--2FEkf" id="content">
     <div class="contentArea__wrapper--1RZ80 contentArea--contentWrap__gradient--GAE4M">
      <div class="columnArea--fullStory__wrapper--1t4GQ columnArea--feed__wrapper--2tKpu">
       <div class="columnArea--fullStory__main--250mb">
        <div class="contentArea__wrapper--1RZ80">
         <header class="contentHeader--simple__wrapper--mN8Ua" id="explainer--what-is-a-blockchain">
          <div class="contentHeader--simple__intro---J1K3">
           <div class="eyebrow__wrap--1BeA8">
            <a class="eyebrow__eyebrow--3MrG8 eyebrow__fullStoryEyebrow--AxoJe" href="https://www.technologyreview.com/topic/blockchain/" style="color:#007fab">
             Blockchain
            </a>
            <span style="color:#007fab">
             /
            </span>
            <a class="eyebrow__fullStoryEyebrow--AxoJe" href="https://www.technologyreview.com/topic/blockchain/bitcoin/" style="color:#007fab">
             Bitcoin
            </a>
           </div>
           <h1 class="contentHeader__title--3ttNf">
            Explainer: What is a blockchain?
           </h1>
           <p class="contentHeader__deck--3A9FE">
            We take a look at who invented blockchains, what applications they’re useful for, and how they are made.
           </p>
           <div class="contentHeader__meta--3u-EJ">
            <div class="byline__wrapper--3vOJH">
             <span aria-hidden="true" class="byline__by--3I70Z">
              by
             </span>
             <ul aria-label="Authors" class="byline__list--2jfa5">
              <li class="byline__author--g26Rn">
               <a class="byline__name--2MpUW" href="https://www.technologyreview.com/author/mit-technology-review-editors/">
                MIT Technology Review Editors
                <!-- -->
                <span class="screen-reader-text">
                 archive page
                </span>
               </a>
              </li>
             </ul>
            </div>
            <div class="contentHeader__publishDate--37zcW">
             April 23, 2018
            </div>
           </div>
          </div>
         </header>
         <div class="contentBody__wrapper--1fP2v">
          <div class="contentBody__overlay--1aZGF">
          </div>
          <div class="contentBody__content--1lbXn" id="content--body">
           <div>
            <div class="">
             <div>
              <div class="gutenbergContent__content--1FgGp html_0">
               <h3>
                What is it?
               </h3>
               <p>
                A public
                <a href="#public" target="_blank">
                 1
                </a>
                , permanent
                <a href="#permanent" target="_blank">
                 2
                </a>
                , append-only
                <a href="#append-only" target="_blank">
                 3
                </a>
                distributed
                <a href="#distributed" target="_blank">
                 4
                </a>
                ledger
                <a href="#Adding" target="_blank">
                 5
                </a>
                .
               </p>
              </div>
             </div>
             <aside class="magazineStory__wrap alignleft">
              <div>
               <h3 class="magazineStory__title" id="magazineStory-title-104451">
                <img alt="The blockchain issue" class="magazineStory__image" height="628" src="https://wp.technologyreview.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/mj18cover-01-3.jpg?w=490" width="490"/>
               </h3>
               <p class="magazineStory__issueDate">
                This story was part of our May 2018 issue
               </p>
               <nav aria-label="Magazine" class="magazineStory__nav">
                <ul aria-label="Links" class="magazineStory__list" role="menu">
                 <li class="magazineStory__item" role="menuitem">
                  <a class="magazineStory__link" href="https://www.technologyreview.com/magazines/the-blockchain-issue/">
                   See the rest of the issue
                  </a>
                 </li>
                 <li class="magazineStory__item" role="menuitem">
                  <a class="magazineStory__link" href="https://www.technologyreview.com/subscribe">
                   Subscribe
                  </a>
                 </li>
                </ul>
               </nav>
              </div>
             </aside>
             <div>
              <div class="gutenbergContent__content--1FgGp html_2">
               <h3>
                What’s that?
               </h3>
               <p>
                A mathematical structure for storing data in a way that is nearly impossible to fake. It can be used for
                <a href="https://www.technologyreview.com/s/610331/when-the-cryptocurrency-bubble-pops-these-tokens-are-built-to-survive/" target="_blank">
                 all kinds of valuable data
                </a>
                .
               </p>
               <h3>
                Who created the first blockchain?
               </h3>
               <p>
                “I’ve been working on a new electronic cash system that’s fully peer-to-peer, with no trusted third party.” These are the words of Satoshi Nakamoto, the mysterious creator of Bitcoin, in a message sent to a cryptography-focused mailing list in October 2008. Included was a link to
                <a href="https://bitcoin.org/en/bitcoin-paper" target="_blank">
                 a nine-page white paper
                </a>
                describing a technology that some are now convinced will disrupt the financial system.
               </p>
              </div>
             </div>
             <div class="contentList__wrap content-right">
              <ul aria-labelledby="104452-val-contentList" class="contentList__listWrap">
               <div class="">
                <li class="contentListItem__wrap">
                 <h3 class="contentListItem__title">
                  Enforcement
                 </h3>
                 <span class="contentListItem__description">
                  <p>
                   Early civilizations used threat of force as retribution for dealing in bad faith when engaging in trade.
                  </p>
                 </span>
                </li>
                <li class="contentListItem__wrap">
                 <h3 class="contentListItem__title">
                  Institutions
                 </h3>
                 <span class="contentListItem__description">
                  <p>
                   The emergence of governments and banks provided organized, central authorities to which we could outsource trust—as long as we trusted them.
                  </p>
                 </span>
                </li>
                <li class="contentListItem__wrap">
                 <h3 class="contentListItem__title">
                  The Network
                 </h3>
                 <span class="contentListItem__description">
                  <p>
                   Blockchains distributed across thousands of computers can mechanize trust, opening the door to new ways of organizing “decentralized” enterprises and institutions.
                  </p>
                 </span>
                </li>
               </div>
              </ul>
             </div>
             <div>
              <div class="gutenbergContent__content--1FgGp html_4">
               <p>
                Nakamoto mined the first bitcoins in January 2009, and with that, the cryptocurrency era was born. But while its origin is shadowy, the technology that made it possible, which we now call blockchain, did not arise out the blue. Nakamoto combined established cryptography tools with methods derived from decades of computer science research to enable a public network of participants who don’t necessarily trust each other to agree, over and over, that a shared accounting ledger reflects the truth. This makes it virtually impossible for someone to spend the same bitcoin twice, solving a problem that had hindered previous attempts to create digital cash. And, crucially, it eliminates the need for a central authority to mediate electronic exchange of the currency.
               </p>
               <p>
                Bitcoin’s popularity began to grow quickly in 2011, after
                <a href="https://gawker.com/the-underground-website-where-you-can-buy-any-drug-imag-30818160" target="_blank">
                 a Gawker article
                </a>
                exposed Silk Road, a Bitcoin-powered online drug marketplace. Imitators called “altcoins” began to emerge, often using Bitcoin’s open-source code. Within two years, the total value of bitcoins in circulation had passed $1 billion.
               </p>
               <p>
                Soon, technologists realized that blockchains could be used to track other things besides money. In 2013, 19-year-old Vitalik Buterin proposed
                <a href="https://www.technologyreview.com/s/612507/ethereum-thinks-it-can-change-the-world-its-running-out-of-time-to-prove-it/" target="_blank">
                 Ethereum
                </a>
                , which would record not only currency transactions but also the status of computer programs called smart contracts. Launched in 2015, Ethereum—and now a host of competitors and imitators—promises to make possible a new generation of applications that look and feel like today’s web apps but are powered by decentralized cryptocurrency networks instead of a company’s servers.
               </p>
               <h3>
                <a id="public">
                </a>
                1. A transaction is born
               </h3>
               <p>
                In Bitcoin, a transaction is the transfer of cryptocurrency from one person (Alice) to another (Bob). In Ethereum, which includes a built-in programming language that can be used to automate transactions, there are multiple kinds. Alice can send cryptocurrency to Bob. Or someone can create a transaction that places a line of code, called a
                <a href="https://www.technologyreview.com/s/612443/blockchain-smart-contracts-can-finally-have-a-real-world-impact/" target="_blank">
                 smart contract
                </a>
                , on the blockchain. Alice and Bob can then send money to an account this program controls, to trigger it to run if certain conditions encoded in the contract are met. A smart contract can also send transactions to the blockchain in which it is embedded.
               </p>
               <figure class="wp-block-image alignfull size-large">
                <img alt="a diagram of two simple transactions on a blockchain" src="https://cdn.technologyreview.com/i/images/explainer-images-1.png?sw=700&amp;cx=229&amp;cy=41&amp;cw=655&amp;ch=501"/>
               </figure>
               <h3>
                <a id="permanent">
                </a>
                2. The transaction is broadcast to a peer-to-peer network
               </h3>
               <p>
                Let’s say Alice wants to send some money to Bob. To do so, Alice creates a transaction on her computer that must reference a past transaction on the blockchain in which she received sufficient funds, as well as her private key to the funds and Bob’s address. That transaction is then sent out to other computers, or “nodes,” in the network. The nodes will validate the transaction as long as it has followed the appropriate rules. Then mining nodes (more on those in step 3) will accept it, and it will become part of a new block.
               </p>
               <figure class="wp-block-image alignfull size-large">
                <img alt="a diagram of a " src="https://cdn.technologyreview.com/i/images/explainer-images-2.png?sw=700&amp;cx=147&amp;cy=0&amp;cw=809&amp;ch=552"/>
               </figure>
               <h3>
                <a id="append-only">
                </a>
                3. The race to create new blocks
               </h3>
               <p>
                A subset of nodes, called miners, organize valid transactions into lists called blocks. A block in progress contains a list of recent valid transactions and a cryptographic reference to the previous block. In blockchain systems like Bitcoin and Ethereum, miners race to complete new blocks, a process that requires solving a labor-intensive mathematical puzzle, which is unique to each new block. The first miner to solve the puzzle will earn some cryptocurrency as a reward. The math puzzle involves randomly guessing at a number called a nonce. The nonce is combined with the other data in the block to create an encrypted digital fingerprint, called a hash.
               </p>
               <figure class="wp-block-image alignfull size-large">
                <img alt="a diagram of a new block of transactions being verified" src="https://cdn.technologyreview.com/i/images/explainer-images-3.png?sw=700&amp;cx=209&amp;cy=32&amp;cw=703&amp;ch=511"/>
               </figure>
               <h3>
                <a id="distributed">
                </a>
                4. Completing a new block
                <strong>
                </strong>
               </h3>
               <p>
                The hash must meet certain conditions; if it doesn’t, the miner tries another random nonce and calculates the hash again. It takes an enormous number of tries to find a valid hash. This process deters hackers by making it hard to modify the ledger. While some blockchain entities use other systems to secure their chains, this approach, called proof of work, is the most thoroughly battle-tested.
                <strong>
                </strong>
               </p>
               <figure class="wp-block-image alignfull size-large">
                <img alt="a diagram of a new block being sent to the network of blockchain miners for approval" src="https://cdn.technologyreview.com/i/images/explainer-images-4.png?sw=700&amp;cx=185&amp;cy=48&amp;cw=736&amp;ch=505"/>
               </figure>
               <h3>
                <a id="Adding">
                </a>
                5. Adding a new block to the chain
               </h3>
               <p>
                This is the final step in securing the ledger. When a mining node becomes the first to solve a new block’s crypto-puzzle, it sends the block to the rest of the network for approval, earning digital tokens in reward. Mining difficulty is encoded in the blockchain’s protocol; Bitcoin and Ethereum are designed to make it increasingly hard to solve a block over time. Since each block also contains a reference to the previous one, the blocks are mathematically chained together. Tampering with an earlier block would require repeating the proof of work for all the subsequent blocks in the chain.
               </p>
               <h3>
               </h3>
               <figure class="wp-block-image alignfull size-large">
                <img alt="a diagram of a new block of transactions being added to a blockchain" src="https://cdn.technologyreview.com/i/images/explainer-images-5.png?sw=700&amp;cx=152&amp;cy=60&amp;cw=775&amp;ch=436"/>
                <path d="M199.49,66.67,133,133.11H66.56V66.67Zm44.31,0-66.46,66.44V354.66h66.46V133.11H354.56V66.67Z" transform="translate(-66.56 -66.67)">
                </path>
                <p>
                </p>
               </figure>
              </div>
             </div>
            </div>
            <div class="sliderAd__wrapper--1vLJw">
             <button class="sliderAd__closeButton--1er6R" type="button">
              <span class="sliderAd__closeText--1dJ37">
               hide
              </span>
              <span class="sliderAd__closeIcon--1scjj">
               <svg height="26" viewbox="0 0 26 26" width="26">
                <g fill="none" fill-rule="evenodd" stroke="#FFF" stroke-linecap="square" stroke-width="4">
                 <path d="M.526.526l19.41 19.41M19.474.526L.064 19.936" transform="translate(3 3)">
                 </path>
                </g>
               </svg>
              </span>
             </button>
             <div>
              <div class="adUnit adUnit__wrapper--1cvS3" loaded="false">
               <div class="site-slider adunitContainer">
                <div class="adBox" id="site-slider-1">
                </div>
               </div>
              </div>
             </div>
            </div>
           </div>
          </div>
         </div>
         <footer class="contentFooter__wrapper--34Woc">
          <h2 class="contentFooter__title--Q53Pb">
           Article meta
          </h2>
          <div class="contentFooter__social--mXO_Z contentFooter__row--FLX38">
           <div class="socialList__wrapper--TEzWE">

                </div>

              </li>
              <li class="socialItem__wrapper--3fIBW socialItem__reddit--1jOOG">

                <span class="socialItem__screenReaderLabel--12OjT">
                 reddit
                 <!-- -->
                 link opens in a new window
                </span>
                <div class="socialItem__icon--1E67j">
                 <svg viewbox="0 0 512 512">
                  <path d="M440.3 203.5c-15 0-28.2 6.2-37.9 15.9-35.7-24.7-83.8-40.6-137.1-42.3L293 52.3l88.2 19.8c0 21.6 17.6 39.2 39.2 39.2 22 0 39.7-18.1 39.7-39.7s-17.6-39.7-39.7-39.7c-15.4 0-28.7 9.3-35.3 22l-97.4-21.6c-4.9-1.3-9.7 2.2-11 7.1L246.3 177c-52.9 2.2-100.5 18.1-136.3 42.8-9.7-10.1-23.4-16.3-38.4-16.3-55.6 0-73.8 74.6-22.9 100.1-1.8 7.9-2.6 16.3-2.6 24.7 0 83.8 94.4 151.7 210.3 151.7 116.4 0 210.8-67.9 210.8-151.7 0-8.4-.9-17.2-3.1-25.1 49.9-25.6 31.5-99.7-23.8-99.7zM129.4 308.9c0-22 17.6-39.7 39.7-39.7 21.6 0 39.2 17.6 39.2 39.7 0 21.6-17.6 39.2-39.2 39.2-22 .1-39.7-17.6-39.7-39.2zm214.3 93.5c-36.4 36.4-139.1 36.4-175.5 0-4-3.5-4-9.7 0-13.7 3.5-3.5 9.7-3.5 13.2 0 27.8 28.5 120 29 149 0 3.5-3.5 9.7-3.5 13.2 0 4.1 4 4.1 10.2.1 13.7zm-.8-54.2c-21.6 0-39.2-17.6-39.2-39.2 0-22 17.6-39.7 39.2-39.7 22 0 39.7 17.6 39.7 39.7-.1 21.5-17.7 39.2-39.7 39.2z">
                  </path>
                 </svg>
                </div>
               </a>
              </li>
              <li class="socialItem__wrapper--3fIBW socialItem__linkedin--TGXGz">
               <a class="socialItem__anchor--qDvt8 mittr-share-link" data-event-action="click" data-event-category="story-footer-share-button-linkedin" data-event-label="https://www.technologyreview.com/2018/04/23/143477/explainer-what-is-a-blockchain/" href="https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.technologyreview.com%2F2018%2F04%2F23%2F143477%2Fexplainer-what-is-a-blockchain%2F&amp;title=Explainer%3A%20What%20is%20a%20blockchain%3F&amp;summary=What%20is%20it%3F%20A%20public1%2C%20permanent2%2C%20append-only3%20distributed4%20ledger5.%20What%E2%80%99s%20that%3F%20A%20mathematical%20structure%20for%20storing%20data%20in%20a%20way%20that%20is%20nearly%20impossible%20to%20fake.%20It%20can%20be%20used%20for%20all%20kinds%20of%20valuable%20data.%20Who%20created%20the%20first%20blockchain%3F%20%E2%80%9CI%E2%80%99ve%20been%20working%20on%20a%20new%20electronic%20cash%20system%20that%E2%80%99s%20fully%20peer-to-peer%2C%20with%20no%E2%80%A6" rel="noopener" target="_blank">
                <span class="socialItem__screenReaderLabel--12OjT">
                 linkedin
                 <!-- -->
                 link opens in a new window
                </span>
                <div class="socialItem__icon--1E67j">

         </li>
        </ul>
       </aside>
      </div>
     </div>
    </main>
   </div>
   <div>
   </div>
  </div>
 </body>
</html>
